statement.tex:
%text A small aircraft encounters bad weather a third of the way into a $600$ km flight and has to slow down by $50$ km/h. As a result, it lands $40$ minutes later than usual.
How long does the aircraft take to fly the same route on a clear day? %

step.context: %text If the \underline\text{speed} of the aircraft on a \underline\text{normal day} be $x$ km/h, then which of the tables below correctly shows the \underline\text{times} taken for the trip on a normal day and on a bad-weather day? %
step.reason:
%text \underline\text{Use the same units of time throughout}.
40 minutes = $\frac{2}{3}$ of an hour.
Hence, if \underline\text{on a normal day} the aircraft flies at $x$ km / hour, then the aircraft will take $\dfrac{600}{x}$ hours for the trip.
But on the \underline\text{bad-weather day}, it will take 40 minutes longer than usual.
Which means, it will take $= \dfrac{600}{x} + \dfrac{2}{3}$ hours. %

step.context: %text If the aircraft reduced it's speed by $50$ km/h a third of the way through, then \underline\text{is the following equation true?} %
step.reason:
%text We have one expression \[ \left(\frac{600}{x}+\frac{2}{3} \right) \] for the time taken \underline\text{on a bad-weather day}.
\underline\text{We need another expression} to form an equation so that we can solve for $x$. And we can get that from the table below.
% \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline & \text{Distance (km)} & \text{Time (hours)} \\ \hline \text{Normal Speed} & 200 & \frac{200}{x} \\ \hline \text{Slow Speed} & 400 & \frac{400}{x-50} \\ \hline \end{tabular}
%text
Hence, the total time taken is also equal to \[ \qquad \qquad T = \frac{200}{x} + \frac{400}{x-50} \] %

step.context: %text Given that on the bad-weather day \[ \quad T = \frac{600}{x} + \frac{2}{3} = \frac{200}{x} + \frac{400}{x-50} \] \underline\text{what is the speed on a normal day (x)}? \textbf{Note: }$350^2 = 122,500$ %
step.reason:
%text We have an equation. We can solve for $x$.
% \begin{align} \frac{600}{x} + \frac{2}{3} &= \frac{200}{x} + \frac{400}{x-50} \\ \frac{1800 + 2x}{3x} &= \frac{200\cdot (x-50) + 400 x}{x\cdot (x-50)} \\ (1800 + 2x) \cdot (x-50) &= 3\cdot (600x - 10,000) \\ \text{or }2x^2 - 100x - 60,000 &= 0 \\ \implies x^2 - 50x - 30,000 &= 0 \end{align} \\ \begin{align} \therefore x &= \underbrace{\frac{50 \pm \sqrt{(-50)^2 -4\cdot(-30,000)}}{2}}_ {x = \frac{-b + \sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}}\\ \implies x &= \frac{50 \pm 350}{2} \text{ or } x = 200, -150 \end{align} %text
$x=-150$ makes no sense. Hence $x=200$ km/h. %
